title: Selfie Stick Stabilizer ( requires 19*6mm airsoft bbs)

description.text:
This is a stabilizer for a selfie stick which uses one of the available "airsoft 6mm ball bearings design" from thingiverse.
I tested a few and i liked the following one :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1799757
which i used in this design.

All rotating parts are moving via 6mm bbs put in the joints.

A foldable handle allows the object to take minimum space.

The selfie stick can still be used normally, be folded, etc. the added piece on the selfie stick is very small.

Weight calibration can be done by moving the camera position, and the standard camera holder of the selfie stick.

if more weight is needed, you can use the bottle cap screw, to screw a bottle at the bottom of the selfie stick.(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2012913)

The overall thing will not consume a lot of filament and will require minimum additional parts :

  • 19 6mm airsoft balls are needed,
  • 1 rod M2 2cm and associated nut
  • 2 small wood screws ( 13mm)

can't be cheaper...

I believe the result is working great, but i do not have a real steady cam to compare...It would be nice to have some comments from experimented steadycam users....

Notes:

It is critical to print the stabilizer without support.
There are 2 Selfie Stick stabilizer versions :

  • SelfieStickStabilizerv2.stl : the version where you can but the bbs once the print is fully finished.

  • SelfieStickStabilizerv2_pausemode : the version where you need to pause the print at z=5.3 or 5.5 and put the bbs while the prnter is paused in the ball bearing. then resume the print process.

with the paused mode, there is no risk to loose a bb...but it can be an issue to intercat with the print process.

The other joint balls can be inserted by forcing after the print is completed.

comments.text: I made one for my daughter. Being younger than 6, she doesn't have the reach on her thumb and index to use a standard sized spinner.
comments.author: jamiehs

comments.text: How long do they spin for?
comments.author: OGERIC

comments.text: The spin time is mostly determined by your bearing. The ones we made will spin for approx. 1 minute due to the light weight. The better your bearing is, the longer the spin time will be.
comments.author: OGERIC

comments.text: That's at 100% fill?
comments.author: RiotImpulse

comments.text: Yes, 90-100% Infill with a cleaned and broken in hybrid ceramic bearing. (We thouroughy clean the bearing, then break it in using an air compressor)
comments.author: OGERIC

comments.text: Thank you so much my main priority is to make it spin as long as possible I'll keep you updated
comments.author: RiotImpulse

comments.text: I made one and it does not spin quite as well, what do you think is wrong with it? What type of bearing are you using?
comments.author: ChicoGonzales

comments.text:
You can use any 608 bearing. Ceramics and hybrid ceramics seem to work the best. You can purchase bearings from local skate shops like zumies, the bones redz and bones redz ceramics work very well.
We clean all of our bearings first with soap and water and use an air compressor to spin them to blow out remaining grease and dry them.
comments.author: ChicoGonzales

comments.text: Skater and quad skate/longboard builder here.  If you'd like the bearings to continue spinning like new, clean with denatured alcohol instead of the soap & water to remove the packing grease, then use a silicone lube.  It still wipes off the outside of the bearing and lasts forever.  I've been cleaning up well used 25-30 year old bearings for my spinners and they're working better than new.
comments.author: RiotImpulse

comments.text: Nice thank you.
comments.author: RiotImpulse

comments.text: Bearing fit was a bit too tight originally, but everything was perfect at 101% on my MP Select Mini. Works very well and I love how it only uses one bearing. Thanks for sharing!

remixed_from.title: Spring loaded extruder for Leapfrog Creatr

title: Remixed: Spring loaded extruder for Leapfrog Creatr

description.text:
My Leapfrog (received a month ago) had problems with filament tolerances I guess. During a print job, the filament was from time to time not transported and the nozzle clogged. Therefore I remixed the extruder from ROB65 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:62468
I made the remix, because I wanted to use the original filament feeding. Now it works very well and the filament change is much easier. For this extruder load the files and the instruction form ROB65 and replace the two idler-latch-V2-xxx.stl files with my files xxxmsa.stl Additionally you will need one M6 nut! You do not need the washers for the motor mount. This was V1! On 17.02.2014 I replaced the stl files with new ones that have 2mm more material to hold the M6 nut.

comments.text: To mount the bearing, you should drill this hole with a 4mm drill (other holes are 3mm). The tube has gone after drilling. This tube is “support material”.

I used those before and just threaded them directly in the plastic

description.text:
Reproduction of the Louvre Aulos (Version 2) :

I've corrected the diameter of the holes (now they're oval as the original), and updated the joints. They're provided with a seat for cork or thread, to ensure a better sealing and avoid leaks as much as possible!

The two pipes (High and Low) of the Louvre Aulos have been modeled and divided in 3 parts (Mouthpiece, Middle and Bell). The lowest note should be an A with a pitch of around 182 Hz (around F#), but, depending on the used reeds, the pitch can change. With a good reed, it is possible to tune it to F# (at 440Hz).

The reeds need to be printed at 0.1 mm layer height and the aulos and the bocal (staple) are fine at 0.25 mm layer height. For a better precision, do not print too fast.

For the reed preparation, please follow the instructions provided by : http://la.trompette.free.fr/Ninob/Manufacture%20of%20plastic%20reeds%20for%20oboe.pdf
They are tied the same way as for oboe.
Don't forget that this is a first version. I'm still working on it, but feel free to ask and comment as you wish!

Thank you!

description.text:
This is a simple adapter to allow you to make use of the makerbot style plastruder tip on a mendel.  This fits just below the extruder stepper assembly.
It contains two holes spaced the same as the makerbot retaining disc.  The holes are NOT offset the same distance from center. One is 1mm closer.  Don't ask me why they did this, but I mimic'd it. ^^
NOTE: You may need to change out the screws as the depth will increase when ;layering on this piece.
NOTE:  You'll probably want to rework the extruder assembly for mendel to remove the cylinder hole at the bottom as, if you use this piece, it is not required.
Prints upside down.  You'll probably need to fit the piece to mendel before putting the extruder tip on it as the mendel x carriage is a tight fit.
Use zip ties to fix your belts.
Did this while experimenting with Nophead's 1/2 twist-in-the-belt idea.  (Which puts the flat side over the non-toothed pulley.)

author: TinkerCave

title: Shower wire shelf hook
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a hook that can be attached to the bottom of a shower basket. It's meant for shower poufs. It doesn't protrude inside the basket at all, so all your shampoo bottles are unaffected.
It was designed for a Smedbo DK1022 Sideline Basic basket, but probably fits many others if they have the same wire measurements.
The measurements this hook was designed for are:
Wire diameter: 3 mm
Wire spacing (center-to-center): 20 mm

Use a caliper to check yours! If your wire diameter is smaller, it's likely that the inter-wire gap is smaller too. Try scaling the hook down by a few percent in your slicer.
Feel free to remix, or message me with your basket wire measurements and I'll see what I can do to help out.

I recommend printing with settings that maximise adhesion (brim, no cooling), because the diameter of the attachment holes is altered if the print shrinks. Try to minimize supports, because the hook gap is difficult to clean up. I printed mine with PLA. Leave a comment if you try with ABS!

To attach the hook, just align the holes with the wire shelf from the bottom and push it up. If the size is correct, it should clip on and carry at least a couple hundred grams easily.

This is a quick and effective way to dampen those motor vibrations resonating through your carbon frame and confusing your Flight Controller.

These are for standard race quad motors 22xx or so. For the little 1306 or 1407 see here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2161130

1.5mm thick and just 0.29g each

Print solid with soft TPU and squish them between your motors and your frame.

TRICKS FOR PRINTING TPU:

I've managed to print NinjaFlex with some pretty crappy extruders

Direct Drive is probably easier. But I've seen 3mm bowden types work.
Print SUPER SLOW
Print HOT like 220-230º
125% or something extrusion multiplier. TPU likes to compress and under-extrude.

good luck.

I'm also selling these in packs of 8 if you want some and can't print them yourself. http://www.ebay.com/itm/253165525844?

description.text:
Although this cyclone filter has been designed from scratch the initial idea came from a separator I saw here on thingiverse made by jaykoehler. I needed a version which could withstand a lot of abuse for onsite building work. It is optimized for a 5 layer perimeter and can be securely fastened with 6mm nuts and bolts. Prints perfect without supports.
It works really well. I designed it to the maximum size my printer could print. Inside I designed a spiral start so that dust is immediately sent in the right direction. I also designed screw in connectors since we use this filter with a lot of different vacuum cleaners with different diameter hoses. So we just need to print a screw connector with the right diameter and don't need to reprint the complete filter. I will put a source file of this connector online so you can adapt it to your needs. Alternatively you can download a conical connector designed by doobedoobedo which will fit various size hoses. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2083622

comments.text: I haven't tested it extensively with plaster dust. I only redesigned it recently and haven't gotten around to plaster works yet.  With regular dust it seems to be working really well so far. The general performance increased drastically since I designed the ramp inside but I would guess as with most of these vortex filters I have used in the past that some really fine dust is still getting through. It's not enough to collect in the bin of your vacuum cleaner but it's enough to over time clog up the vacuum filter. I am sure that in a couple of months time I will have gotten around plaster works. I'll let you know how it works.

comments.text: If it chops it of straight you might be fine. You may end up with an open end since there will be no perimeter on that side. In order to avoid the insert sticking out you could print the inserts at 100% infill and chop 10-15mm of with a hacksaw (or adjust in meshmixer). It should still screw in fine. The other option is to scale the whole thing anyway until it just fits on your plate. Scale the insert with the same amount but save it again to an STL instead of sending it to the printer. Then readjust the part to which your hose connects in Meshmixer or something. I hope this makes any sense.

title: Sintron Prusa i3 lead screw mod

description.text:
These files are suitable for use with a Sintron Prusa i3 to upgrade the Z axis to lead screws in conjunction with Thing: 1140733.

After buying a pair of lead screws and downloading the above Thing files I went to fit them and they were very out for my printers frame. As a result I made a new top and bottom piece to move the smooth rod into the correct position for the X axis ends. The top piece completely replaces the original acrylic part and the bottom piece sits on top of the original acrylic piece.

Longer M3 screws are required for the bottom piece. I've used 4 20mm and 2 25mm screws per side although they would benefit from a few washers on each to effectively reduce the screw length by a fraction.

Note: Due to feedback I have altered the bottom pieces to be more durable but have not printed and tested them out myself. Will update with further feedback.

title: E3D V6 Hotend direct drive extruder

description.text:
This is the cooler door replacement for Satoer's great E3D v6 Easy maintenance carriage to convert it into direct drive. I created this mainly for printing flexible materials.

The main part is the door which is replacement for part "[FelixE3DV6[coolerdoor[V1.STL" (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:484581). There is no need for the original as this new version works for bowder drive as well.

Other parts are for the direct drive (remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53125) with adjustable tension. For complete set you need to print the rest of the parts from Satoer's original design and optionally some parts from LuisCruz's remix for Felix 3.x.

I have printed all my parts using PLA and this DDE has worked fine for almost 2 years now.

Attention! The fan duct from E3D v6 Easy maintenance carriage works only with E3D V6. It will not work properly with E3D V6 Volcano!! I designed an adjustable holder and blower shroud which can be used if you are using Volcano.

Notes:

Carefully turn your Lorei on its side and pull out the 5 rubber feet. Place a spacer on each foot and push the feet back in their respective slots.

Several months ago I received a commission to create a functional prosthetic hand based off of the Phantom Pain hand used in Metal Gear Solid 5. This was for a client who was born without a left hand and grew tired of his standard claw style prosthetic, but didn't want to shell out thousands of dollars for a motorized medical grade prosthetic. The goal was to create something durable, functional and useful on a budget. This is what I came up with. My client has very little left of his wrist, meaning the standard active grip system on other 3D printed prosthetics wouldn't work for him, so I designed a passive grip system using retention springs. This allows the fingers to (more or less) auto-adjust to whatever object they are gripping, and only requires user input to actually open the grip, which is done by pulling the knob at the rear of the forearm section. All 5 fingers normally open and close at once, but there is also a detachable ring connected to the main knob which articulates just the index finger, which can be locked in place to allow greater usability in actions such as typing and pressing buttons.

I'm releasing these files for free because I want them to get into the hands of other people who actually need a prosthetic and can use them to better their lives. The total material cost for the final device is under $100. Here is a breakdown of the additional parts you will need:

Order these;
14x Low profile 4-40 Locknuts: https://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/122/3213/=15s86hk
50x 4-40 7/8" screws: https://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/122/3018/=15s87ym
20X 4-40 5/8" screws; https://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/122/3018/=15s89ba
14x Torsion springs (option to use stronger springs here for increased grip strength, I used 0.353 OD 270 degree right hand torsion); https://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/123/1293/=1ayad1u
10 feet of 1.2mm stainless steel braided cable; https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GYTWM4I/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Normal hardware store stuff;
1x 6-32 Locknut
2x 6-32 40mm screws
2x 6-32 15mm screws
12x 13mm rubber grip pads
7 10mm rubber strip grip pads
Super Glue (for holding the pads in place)
Epoxy putty (For filling the connection between the cables to the pull knob)
Preferred type of foam for internal padding (high density open-cell foam recommended)

Assembly is pretty self explanatory, all parts press fit together (may require some sanding depending on the accuracy of your printer and slicer) and then are screwed into place with the appropriate size/length screw as listed above. The springs are slotted into the appropriate ends of each finger joint before they are put together. The steel wire must be knotted at one end, and then slid through the holes of the fingers to the back of the wrist starting at the finger tip. Please don't hesitate to ask any questions or ask for modifications :)

EDIT: All step files have been posted. Feel free to modify the files however you please, and be sure to post remixes for the community to benefit from!

print_settings.Notes:: Nothing special ...

title: Hexacopter Construction Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hello my like-minded friends ... here is my "New Years Present" for you ;o)

I always wanted to have a Hexacopter so I decided to design one. The result is something like a construction kit to build the Hexa of your needs.

All parts are designed to fit with a small printer like mine (Up!mini) and serve the electronics and other stuff I had at home.

The idea was to have everything very compact, densed and even protected.

There are different parts for the base that you can all combine as you like. So you will have more options to mount all the things to make this copter flying.

You also have the option to do your own holes and slots, therefor I give you some raw parts.

If you'd like to enclose most of the e-parts inside the body, you may need more space. In this case you should print the bases with affix "HIGH".

Also I made two camera mounts in variations for the good old Mobius and the Eachine MC01. You can use them solo or together.

Even without any dampers I have very smooth recordings from the mobius.

There are two different motor booms available, but even six of the small ones will be enough for 6" props. You may combine them as you like (4 short + 2 long f.ex.).
I'd say using the small ones will make the copter more agile, the long ones should make it a bit more smooth flying...

As you can see the ESCs fit into the booms, so you'll have more room inside the body.
The optional feet will click-fit on every position at the booms. If you may want to mount the batteries under the copter, just use the longer feet.

NOTE 0!! The pics above only show one possible build, yours may look completely different.

NOTE 1!! It's on you to make some new parts that may help others to optimize this copter, I'd appreciate and wish this very much.

NOTE 2!! Sorry for the marks on some parts, but I have my reasons for this.

Things you'll need:

Screws (in different lenghts), washers and nuts are all 3 mm (nuts should be self-locking)

Stand-offs for your needs (I'll provide some different lenghts for printing)

Electronic parts I used:

6 x 2204 Motors from Emax
6 x 12A EMCs also from Emax
1 x Naze32 (FC)
1 x Graupner 12L Receiver
1 x Eachine MC 01 (FPV)
1 x Mobius (Doc-Cam)

I've tested this Hexa with a 3S 2200 Lipo and had round about 15 minutes of relaxed flying.

The whole thing has (in my case) a weight of 850g incl. everything, so doing a little math you'll find out that there is much power left to fire this thing around :oD

(Watch out for the additional parts I'll release in a few days. With these you'll be able to build a Quad-Copter in the same design like the Hexa using almost the same parts!!!)

The announced Quad-Parts are available!!! >>> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2023216

Now have fun and please share your MAKE with us :o)

BTW: If you like my contributions and designs, feel free to send me a TIP ... ;o)

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with Taulman 910 and ABS. Both should work fine. The prop guard is pretty thick and strong.

description.text:
This is a 70mm Brushless Quad frame and prop guard. Note: I have built it, but not flown it yet. 3d Printed frames (especially at this size) probably have too much flex, we will see.

Note: There are "risers" built in for the ESC (since its chips need room below) and for the motors (so that props (if you use larger ones) don't hit the FC).

Build Parts
Racestar 4in1 6a ESC
Racestar 10,000kv 1103 Brushless motors
Piko BLX
Crazy Pony AIO Camera/VTX
FuriousFPV MicroRX
RotorX 2535 props cut to 44mm or DYS 2030 props cut to 44mm. DYS Props get around 70g thrust per motor and RotorX (4 blades) get 72g.
Turnigy nano-tech 300mah 2s battery

So far, everything but camera/vtx, and RX (which is only 1g) is around 34g. I'll update more as I get further (probably with a camera mount too).

1-6-2017 - Added Camera mount that fits the CrazyPony AIO Camera/VTX (3.6g!!). Right now, I am hot gluing it to the prop guard (at a 45deg angle), but I might build it into the prop guard or screw it to the standoffs. I printed in PLA and it is a snug fit to hold the camera in. Note the two notches are on the side are for taking a heavy zip tie, cutting it, and hot gluing it in the holes. This serves as a camera protector.

Printed with Taulman 910 and ABS. Both should work fine. The prop guard is pretty thick and strong.

You will need to drill out all the screw holes (for the motor and 4 bottom screws), unless your printer is much better then mine and they come out clean. Otherwise, there isn't much post printing.

Made in TinkerCAD

title: Water Ski Wing Angle Gauge Set

description.text:
New to 3D printing but I am an avid water skier. Thought that fin wing gauges might be a worthy first thing to design and share

Revised 30-April-2017. new version uploaded that changes from raised numbers (as it was in the picture) to hollow numbers. The two benefits are they print faster and they stack together more easily (figured that out the first time I mailed a set to another skier)

Note 20-Oct-2017 I am now recommending printing them out of ABS instead of using PLA simply because PLA can get soft if left out in the direct sun as water ski gear often does. ABS melts at a higher temperature. Also changed to 20% infill just to make them more rugged but they still float.

Revised 31-Dec-2017 Set now includes 9.5 degrees and single of 9.5 degrees available seperate as well.

I printed it standing upright with lots of supports. Getting the ends of the sleeve to print well was a problem that I solved by using the 'dense' feature of Simplify 3D's support system.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed this on an Object 30 Prime with VeroClear at the high quality setting (which I believe is like 14um layers)

title: RigidBot E3D Extruder mount with Rear 40mm Fan

description.text:
I wanted a mount for my E3D on my RigidBot that works with Laser Weld Design's fully constrained block. I liked Walter's idea (and used it as major inspiration) but I wanted a few features his didn't have.

I didn't want to give up any z-height and I wanted to use my 40mm Noctua fan for cooling. I also wanted a part fan with a duct that surrounded the hot end. Finally I wanted to have a fully enclosed filament path because my old extruder kept getting cat hair in it. I would also like to have the filament spool on the table, not up above the machine.

I designed this using Inventor and all parts were designed with Objet printing in mind. They should all work just fine with FDM though.

Tap all of the holes M3 and use appropriate sized bolts to hold everything together. I pre-tapped all holes

The laser cut components are from 1/16" acrylic for the drive gear cover and 1/8" acrylic for the feed tube holder.

The fan duct is printed as a separate assembly so you can make changes easily. The current system is fine with the heat as the Objet resin doesn't burn or melt but if you print out of plastic you may have to put some polyacrylamide tape to insulate it.

There is a small, printed bridge that locks the main cable into place so it cannot come loose. This would probably be useful for all RigidBot owners.

Performance is rock solid and I have had no issues. I'm currently working on a feed system for the filament.

I know my assembly instructions are largely non-existent but if you have questions I'm here! I think this should work with FDM printing but I don't warrant that in any way.

Printer:

Objet 30 Prime

Notes:

I printed this on an Object 30 Prime with VeroClear at the high quality setting (which I believe is like 14um layers)

author: Dawnaur

title: HICTOP Prusa E3D V6 X Carriage Mod

description.text:
This is a mod which allows the use of the E3D V6 hotend with the HICTOP Prusa i3 printer.

It uses a radial fan shroud (credit to adafruit {http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1652852}) compatible with the 50mm radial fan that comes with the printer. The shroud will sit 1-2mm above the printed surface.

Because the stepper motor is now orientated in the x direction rather than the y, the hotend is situated on the left so that no print area is lost. This means that the stock extruder parts (extruder01 and extruder02) must be flipped in order to work with this mod. I was unable to flip them prior to uploading unfortunately. These files are the original ones from HIC.

As a result of the mod, the new printing dimensions will be to 220, 270, 200 (width, depth, height).

Solidworks part files are available upon request.

author: cartledge555

print_settings.Notes:: Make sure support does NOT print inside the part, only touching the building plate.

description.text:
This is a simple fan mount for the BobsCNC RP9 printer incorporating a 50mm x 15mm radial cooling fan. The duct is printable in 2 pieces, the carriage mount and the duct. The duct will need support for the connector. The pieces should attach nicely with some superglue/hot glue. The finished assembly should replace the upper most piece of wood on the carriage, so no extra hardware is need.

I decided to use a radial fan because they produce an considerable amount of airflow while still staying relatively quiet. Here is a link to the fan I purchased ($8):

Wiring

To wire the fan to the RP9 (or any printer using Ramps 1.4) simply snip off the plastic connector at the end of the fan wires, extend the wires (I soldered on two longer wires), and attach to the D9 and corresponding + terminal on the Ramps 1.4 board ( red wire connects to the + terminal).

Using The Fan

In order to maintain a desired hotend temperature during the print, you might have to set the hotend temperature 2-4 degrees higher than what you want. This is because a slight amount of the air from the fan passes and cools the nozzle. As for the fan settings within the slicer, I found that results are best when the fan comes on at around 1~2mm. I've also found that running the fan at 75% dramatically reduces the chance of warping near the bottom corners of the print (Due to too much cooling).

Printer:

BobsCNC RP9v2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

30%

author: Omnicef

description.text:
After seeing that the new camelbaks include a magnetic tube clamp, I wanted one so I modeled this after theirs for my older generation M.U.L.E. NV. I had some neodymium magnets lying around that I used for this.

Composed of three parts:

  • The base clip, which has a cavity for a magnet (1/4x1/8x1/8 in.) to be placed inside. This clip can attach to the sternum strap, or the webbing portion of the backpack strap.
  • The magnet cover, to be slipped over the magnet cavity
  • The tube clamp, which also has a cavity for the same sized magnet to be placed inside

Once you place a magnet inside the base clip, make sure you have the polarity correct for the magnet that goes inside the tube clamp.

Works best with cube or cylindrical magnets.

Everything works great after the print. Once you put everything together, your tube will now attach with the always satisfying action of magnets!

Now your camelbak hose won't be flailing around!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.20mm layer height

Infill:

5%

Printed in PLA

I had to remove the supports inside the base clip with small pliers, which was a bit of a challenge, but in the end, the magnet cover fit tightly inside without having to add any glue.

The magnet in the base clip has a little room to wiggle, which actually creates a nice clicking sound when the tube clamp attracts to it, just like the camelbak version.

The magnet for the tube clamp was a little harder to install because the hole was pretty snug. Had to hammer it in a little, but the uploaded files have accommodated a slightly bigger hole.

My magnets were from K & J magnetics, 17 cents each (1/8 x 1/8 x 1/4 inches)

I looked up the camelbak magnetic tube clamp in Google images, then just modeled it by eye. I used a caliper to take some measurements, like for the tube clip diameter, and the strap slot width on the base clip.

title: Nozzle scrubber pad for Wanhao i3 and others

description.text:
Want to add a new feature to a cheap 3d printer like the wanhao i3? Why not add the ability for the printer to clean the print nozzle before every print. This thing was made to give that feature in a cheap easy to do way. Using Velcro with a sticky back adhesive allows one to easily remove and replace old and worn wiper pads.

This is merely how I did this and can easily be changed. All you really need to do is just stick Some velcro onto the bed and go from there. I use the wiper plate as it means I replace pads in the right place every time.Allowing me to never have to change my start gcode. The only problem is the plate will interfere with some coolers like the diii and ciii. If you are using those coolers I recommend just slapping the Velcro on the bed without the plate. Just try to keep up with the pads location if you can, maybe outline it on the bed if possible. Just too ensure you replace a pad in the right location. See it in action here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ydbMzVH3A2E

Hardware needed

This thing does need a small bit of hardware to get going. You will need
Velcro I used the fabric like side
1 M3 countersunk screw around 20mm (10mm should work if not using a glass bed)
1 to 3 M3 nuts (will need more nuts if you are using a glass bed.
Optional 1 M3 locknut to replace normal nut for tighter fit

How to install

To see if you can do this mod you need to check the back of the heat bed for a hole. The stock build tak surface will cover that hole so the best thing to do is look at the underside of the heat bed for that hole. I know my wanhao i3 v2 has it and I hear that printers like the maker select v2.1 have the hole as well.

Next you cut the Velcro to size around 10mm by 50mm, of course each print will possibly be off so just cut it till it fits with in the indent on the print.

Now that you have it placed on the print we can put the wiper onto the printer. If you have glass you will need to add nuts onto the screw so it offsets the print to lay on the glass bed. I used 2 nuts for this function

If you are using something like the build tak simply make a hole in it where the screw hole in the heated bed is. You will not need height nut as the print will lay on the build surface as is.

Now simply take the normal nut or locknut and tighten the wiper to the heated bed.

Now you have the wiper installed on the printer. We need to tell the printer to use the wiper.

Starting Gcode

All you custom start gcode users may not need this section. Since you can just create gcode to use this upgrade.

Now I actually upgraded my Gcode after we filmed the video above. My Gcode works for my printer, however you may need to edit it for the best performance on your printer. I simply suggest manually moving the printer x,y, and z to the right postion and writing down the positions, then editing the code below

G21 ;metric values
G90 ;absolute positioning
M82 ;set extruder to absolute mode
M107 ;start with the fan off
G28 X0 Y0 ;move X/Y to min endstops
G28 Z0 ;move Z to min endstops
G1 Z4 ;Moves Z up so its not on glass
G1 X100 Y192 ;Moves X and y into middle of nozzle scruber
G1 X79 ;Moves x to left side of velcro wipe
G1 Z2 ;Lower nozzle inro scruber
G1 X125 ;Moves X to Right side of Velcro Wipe
G1 X79 ;Moves X to left side of velcro wipe again
G1 Z7 ;Moves Z above velcro wipe
G28 X0 Y0 ;Move X and Y to home
G28 Z0 ;Move Z to home
G1 Z1 ; Move z off of build plate 1mm
G92 E0 ;zero the extruded length
G1 X50.0 F500 E35.0 ;Start purge line and extrude 35mm
G92 E0 ;zero the extruded length again
G1 Z2 ;Move Z up 2mm
G1 F{travel_speed}
;Put printing message on LCD screen
M117 Printing...

Edit updates.

Edit:11/13/17 added an edits section
Edit:3/20/17 Okay added some new pictures of a used nozzle scrub pad that I removed from the printer.
Edit:2/14/17 Well I have been doing some tests with other cooling shrouds and I have some mixed news. So I have been using a diii cooler remix with the scrubber pad (printed part) for some time. It cuts off some of the bed and overall was really limiting what the machine could do. So I tested two more coolers that connect on the back side of the printer. I tested both the cobra cooler and the ciii cooler. The ciii cooler had the same problem as the diii only since its on the back it limited bed usage even more. So I would overall simply call it incompatible with the Printed Part included here. I was not using the short version I tested at a .2 layer height. The cobra cooler however looks promising as it did not run into the scrubber pad right off the bat. The was at .2 layer height. I am currently thinking that it may be a good choice if you plan to use this mods printed wiper plate and I plan to start using it.
Edit:1/30/17 Hindsight is 20/20 here, I think i might be a smart idea to put something like a insulating washer on before tightening down the scrub pad. I don't know if the nut could scrub off the protective layer on the bottom of the bed.

comments.author: WaveSupportApparatus

comments.text: I have not noticed any melting from all my time of using it. I mostly print pla, but I have printed abs and petg with the Velco on. I have not tried anything like PC or polycarbonite. The plastic dries onto the fabric and gets stuck on the pad.

author: FilamentCorner

title: Heat Sealer For Small Plastic Bags (eg Anti Static)

description.text:
A heat sealer, made from PLA... yes, it really works and doesn't melt into a pile of goo :-)

There are 3 printable parts, the arm, base and tensioner, then you will need to add...

  • Some 0.2mm Kanthal wire - you could use Nichrome, Constantan or thicker wire or whatever, but your power requirements/time to seal would be different. Strung as described below and shown in the pictures, 0.2mm Kanthal will get you about 3.4 Ohms total heater wire resistance.
  • A 5.5/2.1mm DC Panel Socket
  • A 5v coil relay ("sugarcube" size - 15.5mm diameter, eg Omron G5LA-1)
  • A 6mm tact switch
  • A diode (not really important exactly what just for clamping the relay coil's inductive spike, I used a 1n4004 because it was handy)
  • Either a 10W or greater power supply higher than 5v and a miniature DC-DC buck converter set to about 5-6v output, or a 5v 2A power supply (in which case no converter necessary obviously). I personally used a 12v 10W power supply and a buck converter, because that's what I had handy.
  • Wire - preferably silicone (remember if it touches the heater wire you don't want the insulation to melt)
  • M3 and M4 screws and nuts, M4 should be at least 25mm and M3 at least 30mm
  • Two (4mm) ring or fork style crimp connectors
  • Corrugated cardboard ~2.5mm thick (ie, from an old cardboard packing box)
  • Hot glue
  • Kapton tape recommended but not essential

The base prints more or less without supports, a couple places will be rough but "plastic finds a way", add support if your bridging isn't so good. Cut 3 pieces of carboard and fit them into the top of the base these act as the cushion for pressing the sealing wires into.

The tensioner should be printed on it's side so that in use it is not trying to pull the layers apart. Insert two M3 nuts in the holes in the back of the tensioner.

The arm should be printed upside down so the hinge is facing up, no support. On the back of the arm where the tensioner fits there is a cavity which if you want you can fill with epoxy or something for more strength, I didn't need to the plastic is strong enough as is.

It is best to "string" the arm before fitting it to the base as this is quite fiddly. Put a 4mm bolt and nut through the slotted hole on the arm, put the "positive" ring connector on the bolt, start another nut on the bolt but don't tighten it, take a length of heating wire about 35-40cm long and loop the mid-point around the bolt, using your third pair of hands tighten the nut down to hold the wire. Insert the second 4mm bolt at the other end, add a nut, the ring/fork crimped wire for the "negative", a second nut, loop the wires around so you have two strands of wire running the length, 4mm apart, and using your fourth pair of hands tighten the nut. Now hopefully all that remains is to tighten the tensioner. It's probably best to not over-tention. The 0.2mm wire is quite easy to break.

Wiring is pretty straight forward, circuit diagram in the files, one end of the switch can be connected direct to the negative heating-wire 4mm bolt in the same ring crimp so you only need to bring 3 wires out from the back to the arm, positive, negative and one leg of the switch.

Hot glue is used to secure the switch and the power socket (there isn't room for the usual retaining nut for the socket).

If you have some Kapton tape (5mm wide best), a length can be run down the hotwire as I have shown in one of the images, at least for my current Kanthal A1 Ribbon wire this will prevent the hotwire from actually sticking to the the bag and provide a better "sealing" action instead of a "cutting" action, the bag does not stick to the kapton, so you can seal by heating the wire, then release the button but hold it closed until it's cooled, then lift it.

Usage is simple, plug in your power supply (as above assuming using 0.2mm Kanthal wire, you will want about 5v at 2A either using a miniature DC-DC converter tucked in the base so you can apply a 12v or greater supply, or directly using a 5v 2A one), put the bag in the obvious place press down the arm gently and hold the button for about 5-7 seconds to seal (exact time varies depending on bag etc, some I have take about 7 seconds, some take closer to 10), as the wire heats and expands a fraction just press down a little more to take up the slack. After releasing the button keep pressing down for a couple seconds before removing the bag, if the bag sticks to the wire just click the button for a second and it will come off, try not to twang the wire or you might break it.

description.text:
Tired to sort games notes before starting the Illuminati game? I designed this drawers to help you (actually me, but I sincerely hope it would help you as well!!): the notes are easy to extract from the drawers and fit in the original game box.
Why a white drawer? Initial version, slope too steep. And then? No longer got white PLA, I had to use a black roll!
There might be many versions, here is mine: Illuminati by Steve Jackson.

Doesn't Matter

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

30% rectangular

Notes:

I use Slic3r, here are some of my parameters (FYI, highly depend on your printer)

  • 1st layer: 0.2mm
  • layer heigh: 0.1mm
  • Avoid crossing perimeters: yes (avoid some filament loss)
  • solid layers: bottom could be avoided but struggled to get it worked!
  • speeds: I reduced everything!
    • 50mm/s perimeters
    • 70mm/s for infill
    • 100mm/s for travel
    • 60mm/s for max print speed

I have made integrated T-Nut and bolt, so T-bolt. Bolts have standard M8 threads.

title: Crown - for wise mans n' dolls n' stuff...

description.text:
This Christmass, does your wise-man need to dress more smartly? "PLA, we bring, to crown Him again...", if that's how you sing it? Or maybe u just need a crown for something? Well, today's your lucky day then!
Model is approximatly 5/8 inch diameter, or about the right size for a Barbie/Kelly doll. It also has some holes that can be enlarged for sewing on.

Must print with raft! If you want to modify:
1) Be careful about scaling down as it's pretty thin as is.
2) The Blender file used the "array modifier" which seemed like a good idea at the time, but leads to vertical seams between crown sections which could possibly break over time. You may want to "apply" everything, then weld verts to get rid of this nonsense. :P

author: miguelmiguel

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
A spacer for the potentiometers of the Hofner Verythin Deluxe.

The problem (?):
The stock knobs on (at least, my) Verythin were not having the same distance from the body. Some where too high, one was touching the body etc.

When I remove the electronics (It's a tough work, as you have to take them out from the f-holes), I noticed that between the pot and the body, Hofner had a grover washer and another one (bigger) screw nut (as a spacer).

I remove them and design one spacer, that fits exactly on the stock potentiometers, to replace the screw nut. Also corrected the height, so when installed (with the grover washer on top), the knobs are aligned and not touching the body.

I can't guarantee that all Verythin Deluxe have the same shaft/height potentiometers, but that spacer works for me :-)
Also it's a 2 minutes print, so it's worth a try.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: French Door Refrigerator - Crisper Center Rail Support (W10326469)

description.text:
We have a refrigerator that uses the crisper center rail W10326469. It is a part that breaks almost yearly because all of the weight in the drawers is placed at the front clip of the center rail. a 4mm thick piece of plastic, roughly 38mm wide. That can be a lot of weight for a small piece of plastic. After replacing it yet again, I decided the design was in dire need of improvement.

This is by no means an elegant solution and I am working on designing it so it blends better with the design of the refrigerator (like replacing the pencil with a foot and a dowel rod) but, after a test, it seems to be working great!

Side note, the refrigerator in question is a Maytag MFI2569YEM0. If I understand correctly, this part is used in many refrigerators. A similar part might even be used... IN YOURS! See if this will prevent any issues!

comments.text: Great idea! I have added it to my collection of refrigerator parts, thanks!

title: Shoe Lever (thumb lever) for Velbon Tripods

description.text: This is my current approximation of the 'shoe lever' for a Velbon Sherpa camera tripod. This piece holds a camera, mounted on a Sherpa shoe, onto the tripod. It is based on my measurements of about 1/3 of the remains of a broken one, and some online pictures, so I know it isn't exact. It worked for me, and emendations are strongly encouraged.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

50%+

Notes:

High resolution helps because it needs to slide against other parts. Infill of 100% might be better still, as this little piece holds your expensive camera on your tripod.

Using Makerbot's software, my first print failed to print the walls of the thumb-rest, and that broke off almost right away (I'm not even sure how it survived printing) but it was fine the second time - not sure why. It actually works fine without the thumb-rest, but the original had one, so I included it.

I've attached a photo of how the spring (if you still have it) fits in (this is my first print, which didn't print the walls of the thumb-rest part for some reason).
With some very fine tuning, and some lube (I used a wax-based dry bike chain lube) this does work with the auto-lock on the Sherpa 200R, but it's finicky.

Best guess

I didn't really design this - it's a guess at replacing a part from a manufacturer that's no longer in business.

I had about 1/3 of the original piece, and a pdf of the users' manual containing a drawing that includes the object, but very small, part of an assembly, and from one angle. I also had a good electronic caliper for measuring, simple algebra, and the patience to render the object with small adjustments to make it look about right.

author: TrogdorTheBurninator

title: MLK March on Washington Button & Lesson Plan

description.text:
Reproduction of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom button. Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his "I have a dream" speech during this march and is seen wearing the button in photos of the event.

Files are available for 3D printing including a dual extrusion version, laser cutting and 2D printing. Multiple source images were used to create the vector image for this design with http://buttonmuseum.org/buttons/march-washington-jobs-and-freedom providing the primary visual source material.
CCSS

Introduction The 1960s Civil Rights Movement sought to end segregation and discrimination against African Americans. One of the largest political rallies of the Civil Rights Movement was the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom. A key moment of the march was the "I have a dream" speech delivered by Martin Luther King, Jr. from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial to a crowd of 200,000-300,000. The effects of the March on Washington include building momentum for the passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/March_on_Washington_for_Jobs_and_Freedom Martin Luther King Jr. wearing March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom button. By Rowland Scherman; restored by Adam Cuerden (U.S. National Archives and Records Administration) [CC0 or Public domain], via Wikimedia Commons Objectives Students will investigate and explore the legacy of Martin Luther King Jr. and the Civil Right Movement through a reproduction of a button from the 1963 March on Washington. Students will design, make and share a historical artifact that illustrates a significant aspect of the Civil Rights Movement.

Investigate: What is the significance of this button? Teacher presents button to students and ask them to research and present why it is significant. (Teacher could tell students that a button has been donated to their history class and the students need to report on it's historical significance. Or the students could be given the role of appraisers/expert and asked to explain the value of the piece. See Antiques Road Show or American Pickers as examples.) Explore: Take Action Teacher provides students with copies of the button to wear. (See included pdf.) Students are asked to plan/participate in an event/project/presentation to commemorate or recreate the march.
-Examples might include a march through the school or creating photos/videos of students marching. Students could also green screen themselves into photos/videos of the time period. Students might also take on the persona of people from the era and conduct historical interviews from the march. Design/Make/Share: Civil Rights Era Artifact Authentic Challenging Problem: Create a historical artifact that represents the legacy of Martin Luther King Jr. or illustrates a significant aspect of the Civil Rights Movement. Research and then design the artifact in 3D modeling software such as Tinkercad or Morphi. Make the artifact using a 3D printer. Iterate the design if necessary for printability. Take photos of finished design. Share design on Thingiverse. Be sure to include a photo and key fields such as summary, category and tags. Teacher may want students to document process with the Mini Maker Notebook - Thingiverse Edition http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:93186

3D Printer with 2 contrasting colors of filament
OR
2D Printer and Button Maker

description.text:
Inspired by sirmakesalot's design.

You may need sand the cylinder to make the piston fit smoothly. Dremel's smallest round sanding bit is best for that. Also make sure the piston is smooth on the outside. As there is just a 0.5mm tolerance.

Use 1.75 filament as a pistons pin, friction fitted inside. Lock the crankshaft in place with a hot knife or something. I used a utility blade and a lighter. Melt the pin flat on the crankshaft, just make sure that you don't melt the parts together. You can also just sand down the pin flat against the crankshaft if you don't mind if the crankshaft can be removed/pops out sometimes while handling.

title: C4 DeWalt 660 Tool Mount for MPCNC 525 w/ HicWic Universal

description.text:
My original Quick Change DW660 mount had an arm snap in the cold weather. I reprinted in PETG but that one wiggles just a bit too much.

I took the opportunity to remix the Dewalt ShapeOko mount onto a Hicwic quick connect blank which also allows using a smaller profile dust boot and reattaching the tool-less collar to the Dewalt.

I also added an outer bracket so the mount can be squeezed in place as it now sandwiches the Hicwic mounting plate.

This is my new Dust Boot, so much more convenient than the last one!
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:410266

The Dewalt will sit a little lower in this than the standard mounts, be sure to clamp it as high in the bracket as it'll go to reclaim some of that space.

Uses 4x

  • 3/16" bolts 3" long (I hate metric Allen keys/bolts)
  • Nuts!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SnooN0hqVVg

comments.text: In the main picture, the STL file that is colored blue noticed it has a notch so the front part can sit lower than the holding bracket. I was curious why you did that since I'm basing my design for a different tool off your design. Was it for a structural/functional reason other than to give you more Z axis height by making sure the tool got the bit down as low as possible?
comments.author: The3rdIcon

comments.text: The main mount (Black Part in my pics = HicWic mounting bracket) has a floor.  The notch on the back of my part sits flush on the floor and flush on the top of the HicWic part.  Full contact on all touching faces; front, back and bottom.

description.text:
This is another remix of the cradle. Once again, use the pins from the source.
This cradle is for spool that are as small as 61mm (minus the outer walls of the spool) and as a big as 82mm (with the outer walls of the spool).

Although the thinner support for the bearing is solid enough to hold the 1kg spool comfortably, I would suggest to push the pin through the stronger support first (as seen as in the pictures). It does bend a bit when pressure is applied toward the other support. I suppose I could have made the outer support of the other side thinner as well but when I measured it in Meshmixer, the size (82 mm) was ample enough for the spool I had (Monoprice Orange ABS). If anyone want me to make the thinner outer support on the other side, please mention it in the comment. =)

It was a bit harder to make than my other smaller cradle since I had to make a couple more slices through the cradle so I could keep the other proportions. Basically, if you only slice the outer support for the side of 1 bearing and reduce the scale, you end up with a space that is less than 1 bearing between the two supports. I had to slice the middle part between the two supports to scale it up so the space for the bearing would remain the same, despite a thinner outer support.

Also, I've included the meshmixer file.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

I printed with 0.8 mm walls, and top/bottom layers.

Tired of sales people knocking on your door?  Hang this on your door and hope that solicitors in your neighborhood can read (most, but apparently not all, can read).  
I needed a "No Soliciting" sign for our front door and I was not pleased with the stickers I could get at the local hardware store....they are functional, but not so great looking. So I turned to my Makerbot to produce exactly what I wanted.  I thought plastic would not be too durable in the sunlight, even if painted and I wanted to try my hand at metal casting since I had never done that before.  I designed the sign to be about 8" long so I split it into two pieces to fit on my TOM.  I added some sprue/vent structures into the design to allow casting in pewter.  I experimented with several different casting mold and sprue structures and found that this seemed to work best.  Since this is a one-sided piece (back side is flat), I used a piece of porcelain tile as the back half of the mold, and used plaster as the front half of the mold.  I glued the plastic master to the tile with a little acetone, built up a box around it, poured in plaster, baked the plaster, removed the plastic master, then poured the molten metal.  That is the basic process.  To finish it, I sanded/polished the metal then painted the background red.  
I think it came out really nice and expands the capabiltiy of the Makerbot beyond just plastic.  Next time I want to try some "lost-ABS" or "lost-PLA" type casting so I can create more complex geometries.
This was my first experiments with molding metal, so I made lots of mistakes and there are probably better ways to do things.  Please be careful with molten metal if you try this yourself....it is hot and dangerous.
It is fun learning a new skill.

• Print the sign in two pieces
  • Sand the junction between the two pieces so they are perfectly flat and mate together (the bottom few layers of plastic tend to stick out a little)
  • Use a little acetone to bond the pieces together and bond them to a flat porcelain tile....just a little acetone.
  • Flood the whole surface with acetone and quickly dump it out. Then let it air dry a few minutes. This will smooth out the surface a little and make it easier to release from the plaster mold.
  • Build up a box around the plastic (I used wood and hot melt glue to stick it to the tile.
  • Mix up some thin plaster of Paris (about 1:1 ratio of powder to water) to fill the bottom of the mold. Slosh it around good to make sure it fills all the details and the bubbles come to the surface.
  • Mix up some thicker plaster (about 2:1 ratio of powder to water) to fill the rest of the mold.
  • Let the plaster harden for about 30 minutes then remove the wood mold and remove from the tile.
  • I found it best to leave the plastic master in the plaster at this time. If I try to remove it, it tends to damage the plaster. Instead....
  • Heat the plaster in an oven at about 200F for about 1 hour. The plastic will soften and bubble a little and be very easy to remove from the mold. It destroys the plastic, but the mold will be perfect. Clean up any stay plaster. Note: I tried various release agents on the plastic to get it to release from the plaster (WD-40, petroleum jelly) but none seemed to work as well as the method above.
  • Continue to heat the plaster at about 450 for a couple hours to drive off ALL the moisture and pre-heat the mold.
  • Pre-heat the porcelain tile as well in the oven.
  • As the mold/tile are heating, melt your pewter. I used some lead free pewter from http://www.metalshipper.com/pewter/pewter-bars.html. It came in small bars that were easy to deal with and the price seamed reasonable. I metaled the metal on a little camp stove in a cheap stainless steel measuring cup.
  • Remove the mold/tile from the oven, clamp them together and hold them vertically. Pour in the metal into the main funnel until it starts to emerge from the 4 vents.
  • The metal will cool in about 10 minutes then extract the metal piece. It seems to damage the plaster mold so I could only get one piece per mold.
  • Clean off any extra plaster and pewter flashing. Sand the surfaces with progressively finer grits til it is polished. I used 120, 180, 300, 400, 600, 1000, and 1500, grit paper by hand. It only took about 15 minutes to polish it nicely.
  • I spray painted the inside with 4 coats of red paint. Then polished again with 1000 and 1500 to remove the paint on the top surfaces only.
  • Hang on your door and hope that solicitors in your neighborhood can read (most but not all can read apparently).

title: BigBox Dual Hybrid mounting bracket for BLTOUCH z probe

description.text: This is a retaining bracket which holds the BLTOUCH z probe in the same location as the existing IR z probe. The existing IR probe wiring can be used as is, along with a small change to the BLTOUCH Dupont connector wiring. One additional wire is needed to hook up the servo mechanism in the BLTOUCH to the RUMBA board.

Printer:

BigBox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

100 %

Notes:

Print the retaining bracket using a non-brittle plastic. I used PLA-Plus from eSun; it is easy to print with and much less brittle than standard PLA yet costs about the same as standard PLA.

The bracket holds the BLTOUCH in place using the same screws and nuts that currently hold the IR z probe in place. In the photo, the bracket is white.

Note that the wires coming from the BLTOUCH have been regrouped in the 3-pin Dupont connector so that they match the existing connection for the IR probe.

Also note that the BLTOUCH brown and black ground wires are redundant, so only one needs to be connected.

In summary, a single extra wire is needed to connect from the RUMBA board to the BLTOUCH servo wire.
This was created using OpenSCAD. The source file is included.

After searching Thingverse for a Raspberry Pi2 box that allows me to allow me to constantly open up and add circuitry, I realized that there isn't such a box.

As such, I designed this box that open up on side the GPIO pin is on. The round holes on the box is meant for 3.5" headphone socket. I have relays, IR receiver and transmitter connected through these socket.

The top and bottom part of the box is held together with the use of M3 countersunk screws.

Recently I added some hardware to my gun cabinet to find that the 1/2 I was using for the rifles was too small so I removed the shelf I kept the handguns on and created these little organizational tools. The first is a trigger hanger. I designed it to fit my H&K VP9 which is a polymer frame so the trigger guard is wider than a metal frame so it fits both. The second is a magazine hanger for either a 30 rd banana clip or a 10 rd magazine for the AR-15 or M-16. Third is a hanger for the spare magazines for the H & K, it is a double stack 9mm so it would probably fit others. Gloc, CZ, ???. Inside diameter is 23 x 33 mm .
This little cute boat is designed for my baby girl Vivian.

description.text:
HAVING VERY LITTLE PATIENCE, I DECIDED AGAINST PRINTING FORTY DRAG CHAIN LINKS ONE AT A TIME. THIS MOD WAS DESIGNED FOR THE ADVOCATES OF FLEXIBLE FILAMENT AND SHOULD FIT MORE THAN AT LEAST TWO ON A PRUSA I3. IT IS A VERY SIMPLE DRAG CHAIN MADE OF TPU. AGAIN THIS CHAIN WOULD WORK WITH TPE AS WELL AS NINJA FLEX, FILAFLEX AND PROBABLY ANYTHING WITH FLEX YOU CAN FIND.

  • IF YOU HAVE HAD BAD LUCK WITH INDIVIDUAL DRAG CHAIN LINKS DE-LAMINATING, SPLITTING OR BREAKING THIS ONE IS FOR YOU.

-I ADDED THE ADDITIONAL FILE SO THAT MORE THAN ONE CAN BE ZIP TIED TOGETHER FOR LONGER DISTANCE AXIS'.

-YOU SHOULD PRINT IT WITH 25% INFILL OR LESS FOR THE BEST FLEX, FOR TPU, AND MIGHT EVEN BE ABLE TO STRAIGHTEN THE CHAIN OUT WITH A HEATED BED THOUGH THAT DOES SEEM UNLIKELY.

  • THERE ARE TWO HOLES ON EACH END WHICH SHOULD MAKE IT EASY TO ATTACH IT TO A MOUNT FOR YOUR PRINTER OR TO BE SCREW IN TO SOMETHING

-SCALED UP WITH ALWAYS WORK AS WELL.

comments.text: Indeed to take advantage of the flexibility is a good idea ! Plastic hinges e;g. work fine and last a long time !

This is a free model so don't try and sell it to get filthy rich because it took my a long time to make. At least 5 min and that's a life time when you have really bad adhd like me and just ate a bunch if riddlin.

Please share your prints. This could be the next big thing 3D printing has been waiting for. A real benchy.

description.text:
This is a collection of clamps for my CNC machine. I couldn't find any good ones so I made my own in OpenSCAD.
I designed everything around using M4 bolts. It seems typical CNCs use larger bolts, but I wanted to keep mine small, since my CNC is a little smaller (MPCNC 2' x 3'). I made the SCAD file configurable for this so if you prefer to use M8 or whatever, go right ahead.
*Update I've switched to 1/4" bolts. They're easier to find, especially at longer lengths. The STLs with QI in the name are for this size.

comments.text:
I think I understand what you are saying. It does seem like STLs generated from Customizer contain more surfaces than there should be. If you open the original SCAD file in OpenSCAD, you can tweak the parameters similar to Customizer, render, and then export STLs that are better and easier to post-process. Unfortunately, STL isn't really a format that is meant to be processed. In terms of 2D, it's like an exported raster image, as opposed to a scalable vector (or drawing file). STL is really meant to be the last step before 3d printing. Does that make sense?
If you are looking to just print STL files, my personal favorite is Slic3r. It's very similar to Cura. If you don't mind paying a little bit, Simplify3D is always a good app to have for 3d Printing.
As for STL manipulation, here a good list of apps: https://all3dp.com/free-stl-editor-open-edit-stl-file/. TLDR: FreeCAD, SketchUp, Blender, MeshMixer, MeshLab, 3D Slash, SculptGL

title: Sewing box from Lockable Present Ornament

description.text:
I made many Lockable Present Ornament, many of then wrapped at beginning.
They are waste? No, I looking for what they can do at their rest life time, maybe a pencil holder. Finally, I find Sewing box by NicApicella.
These small steel plates come from my daughter's assembling toy, thanks to her :)

I didn't design the assemble, just drill holes directly, so no design map to share, sorry.
My simple steps:

  1. for the right 3 boxes, find the center of center box, drill the first hole there.
  2. Mount the longest steel plate on it, and drill the other 2 holes related to it on the other 2 boxes. Angle is not critical, just keep enough nut space inside, before drilling. And mount them.
  3. As to these 2 short plates, similar. Notice, make it parallel to the longest one, otherwise, your boxes will going crook.
  4. Left 3 boxes, ...
  5. mount two group boxes together. I believe you can make it !

The box bottom stl file is the same with original one, nothing changed.

remixed_from.title: LED strip mount for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 fan bracket

title: Wanhao i3 V2.1 LED Bar Light Strip Mount Mk2

description.text:
This is a LED light strip holder that mounts to the front cooling fan holes on your V2.1 Wanhao and its clones.
The Mk2 versions have been added!!! This version has a slightly better wire holding system and much lower walls. It also shrunk the screw holes and capped the back of them for a much better fit. The Mk2 includes a couple different style light bars my favorite being the Ultra High due to its very small profile and the Low due to the fact that it actually lights up the very tip of your nozzle!!!

Requirements:

  • Wanhao i3 or one of its clones.
  • Rear cooling setup like my 50mm cooler. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2022857
  • LED Light Strip http://tinyurl.com/hv63d8p
  • JST XHP-2 connectors to make a Y cable for you Extruder Heat sink Fan Wire.

Installation:
Install the LED Strip(you will have to cut a sliver off most likely)
Solder a JST XHP-2 connector to around 3in of wire.
Make a JST XHP-2 splitter(Y cable) so you can pull power for the LED's from your heat sink cooling fan.
Install the splitter.
Remove your stock cooling fan.
Install the LED light bar with the stock hardware.
Contact me directly if you need any help!

Please leave comments for improvements youd like to see

Future Improvements:
Side Mount Version. ETA Feb2017

title: Axis and Tower Markers for 3D Printers

description.text:
playing with a printer a lot? specifically a delta with 2020 extrusion towers? ever get mixed up which tower is which? print these off and add them to your printer, you can use them to mark you axis' towers so you never forget again

update 1:
print with the base down and support on (pillars worked well for me, other directions will result in lots of small support to remove)
there are 2 group stl files included, 1 has x,y,z and H, the other just xyz
they are oriented in the best direction

build info:
the files you are most concerned with are:
indented_x_asm.STL
indented_y_asm.STL
indented_z_asm.STL

and the blank base is:
2020Alextr_15mm_base_block.STL

all of the others are for you to do as you please with

the .amf files are just new versions of .stl, they would contain extra info that would be beneficial for multi material printing (mostly flex mixed and colour printing)
as i have not set any extra settings in them they are just as good as .stl files at this point, i know slic3r does accept them

included are all of my solidworks construction files, if you want to play with them

there are 2 versions of each letter, indented, better for visibility and solid
currently only the indented letters are on the base piece, but i have included the blank base if you want to add them yourself

kossel delta

title: BlueTooth Speaker Enclosure for TDA7492P INSMA BT Board

description.text:
12/03/2017 - Added an updated speaker grill
12/18/2017 - Added a 12mm Spacer with Camfer for certain 4" speakers that need more clearance.

This is a build based on a $12 2x50 Watt Bluetooth 4.0 Stereo Audio Board: https://www.amazon.com/TDA7492P-Amplifier-Wireless-Bluetooth-Receiver/dp/B01BTJZFY6/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1483680968&sr=8-1&keywords=insma

11/21/2017 Update - This appears to be a closer match to my board:
https://www.amazon.com/INSMA-Hifi-Mini-Bluetooth-Audio/dp/B01KFZN6Y6/

*Power toggle button was removed on the originally linked design. (the first link above).
** let me know if you have a similar card and need a small tweak to make your card work in this case.

This little $12 (now sells for $15-25 on average) board is fantastically loud and sounds great to me. Well suited for the Good'Nuff audio hackers. This project is not recommended for audiophiles - the rest of us don't understand the concept of $50,000 speakers :)

To build this my son and I salvaged an old rear channel Stereo speaker set each with a 4" mid range speaker and a 2" tweeter.

Supplies you'll need:

  1. The TDA7492P Audio Board linked above.
  2. Two 4" (101.6mm) speakers with the 4 screw holes spaced square 80mm apart.
  3. Two 2" (50.8mm) tweeters with the 4 screw holes spaced square 44mm apart. *I Recommend adding High-Pass capacitors to the tweeters for better sound (many have filters included). More info on High-Pass filters here: http://www.carstereo.com/help/Articles.cfm?id=1 and on google.
  4. A 12V DC Power supply.
  5. A soldering Iron
  6. qty 12 M3 machine screws about 10mm to 12mm long.
  7. qty 12 nyloc M3 nuts
  8. qty 8 wood screws ~2.7mm to ~3.5mm diameter and ~20mm to ~25mm long. (redrill pilot holes if you have larger wood screws. These are used to fasten the 4" speakers on the ends.
  9. Speaker wire. Give each speaker about 12" slack to make the system easier to work on (better clearance).
  10. qty 4 15mm M3 Standoffs

Build Instructions:

  1. Print one "BlueToothBox02.slt" main tube.
  2. If you have 4" speakers with giant magnets (the 50W ones that I used did) you'll also need to print two spacers "BluetoothSpeaker_Spacer12cm_01.stl" to put on the ends (for larger magnet clearance).
  3. Print the button set "Buttons_4_BlueTooth01.stl"
  4. Optionally print two Grills, and two tuning ports.
    *Full Disclaimer - I did not science the tuning ports. So audiophiles rage away :)
  5. Wire up the speakers and power to the board first and test it out.
  6. Turn tube upside down and carefully place the buttons in the pre-drilled holes on top. The Short button is the power button. Put Tape on the buttons (on top outside of main enclosure) to hold them in place for step 8.
  7. Screw 4 Standoffs and Nuts into Audio Board with Standoffs pointing upward.
  8. Disconnect speakers and leave wiring connected to Audio board and attach Audio board to top of tube with Standoffs aligning with screwholes on top, while making sure that you slide the board under the taped buttons. Screw in the 4 M3 screws through the Main Chassis Tube and into the standoffs on the Audio Board.
  9. Once Audio Board is screwed in you can remove the tape. The buttons should now work and will be a little loose.
  10. Screw in the tweeters with M3 screws and Nyloc nuts. Connect tweeter speaker wires to Audio Board.
  11. Feed the DC power supply wire through the little hole centered on the back of the main tube. I suggest that you purchase (or salvage) an optional female DC power supply port and mount it on the back. I salvaged mine from some random electronics that I was throwing out.
  12. Connect the 4" speakers and fasten them with the wood screws. If you are having issues with the speaker magnet hitting internal parts then use the optional 12mm spacers (mentioned in step 2).
  13. Slide on the grills if you want them. - Print one pair of the two designs posted.
  14. Optionally use a Sharpie to color in the buttons and corresponding words on top.
  15. Plug it in, power it up, and play some music.

Final Tweak: Drill a 2 to 3 mm diameter hole just above (about 4mm) the "P" in PLAY to be able to see the LED light inside. Updating the design with this hole built in is on my 3D Printing ToDo Stack. I am considering chopping/dremeling a clear toothbrush neck to make a cheap light channel for this.

Printer:

Maker Select i3 and PowerSpec Ultra

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Comment if you have questions or suggestions or get stuck on any steps. Have fun.
